text: The word "besprizornyj/besprizornik" appeared in the Soviet era, and according to the [National corpus of the Russian language](https://processing.ruscorpora.ru/graphic.xml?graphic_from_result=1&lang=ru&mode=main&nodia=1&req=беспризорный&smoothing=3&sort=i_grstd&text=lexform#toggle), it was typical in print in particular between 1920s-1940s. Literally meaning "unsupervised", it was usually used to refer to homeless children, orphans. Boris Zhitkov, author of children's books (1882-1938), wrote a short story titled "Besprizornaya koshka" (Unsupervised cat), published in his volume "Rasskazy o zhivotnykh" (Short Stories about Animals), 1935.
ru_trans: Слово "беспризорный/беспризорник" появилось в советскую эпоху, и, согласно [Национальному корпусу русского языка](https://processing.ruscorpora.ru/graphic.xml?graphic_from_result=1&lang=ru&mode=main&nodia=1&req=%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9&smoothing=3&sort=i_grstd&text=lexform#toggle), было особенно распространено в печати между 1920-ми и 1940-ми годами. Буквально означая "без присмотра", слово обычно использовалось для описания бездомных детей, сирот. Борис Житков, автор детских книг (1882-1938), написал рассказ "Беспризорная кошка", который был опубликован в его сборнике "Рассказы о животных" (1935).

text: An allusion to Alexander Radishchev's *Journey from St. Petersburg to Moscow* (1790), in particular its epigraph, which was taken from Vasilii Trediakovsky's "Telemakhida" (1766): "чудище обло, озорно, огромно, стозевно и лаяй" ("a beast who is enormous, disgusting, a-hundred-maws and barking"). Read the original [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/1850/index.html) and an English translation [here](https://archive.org/details/journeyfromstpet0000radi). Similar wording is used on the following page: "преогромна волчица" ("huge she-wolf").(R179/E52-53). Animal motif.In chapter 4, Ilya described the homeland in these terms (cunning, deceptive, rich yet poor at first sight): "Распрекрасно снаружи — родина. Вроде — мать, но хитра поразительно, охмуряет. Поначалу все кажется — земля как земля, только бедная, нету в ней ничего. Но обживешься, присмотришься — все в ней есть, кроме валенок."

Тредияковского (1766): "чудище обло, озорно, огромно, стозевно и лаяй". Прочитать произведение можно [здесь](https://ilibrary.ru/text/1850/index.html), а английский перевод — [здесь](https://archive.org/details/journeyfromstpet0000radi). Похожая формулировка употреблена на следующей странице: "преогромна волчица". В главе 4, Илья описывает родину так: "Распрекрасно снаружи — родина. Вроде — мать, но хитра поразительно, охмуряет. text: An allusion to Alexander Radishchev's *Journey from St. Petersburg to Moscow* (1790), in particular its epigraph, which was taken from Vasilii Trediakovsky's "Telemakhida" (1766): "чудище обло, озорно, огромно, стозевно и лаяй" ("a beast who is enormous, disgusting, a-hundred-maws and barking"). Read the original [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/1850/index.html) and an English translation [here](https://archive.org/details/journeyfromstpet0000radi). Similar wording is used on the previous page: "Россия-матерь огромна, игрива и лает, будто волчица во мгле" ("Mother Russia is huge, playful, and she barks like a she-wolf in the fog"). In chapter 4, Ilya described the homeland in these terms (cunning, deceptive, rich yet poor at first sight): "Распрекрасно снаружи — родина. Вроде — мать, но хитра поразительно, охмуряет. Поначалу все кажется — земля как земля, только бедная, нету в ней ничего. Но обживешься, присмотришься — все в ней есть, кроме валенок" (R179/E52-53). Animal motif.
ru_trans: Отсылка к "Путешествию из Петербурга в Москву" А. Радищева (1790), в частности, к эпиграфу, взятому из "Техемахиды" В. Тредияковского (1766): "чудище обло, озорно, огромно, стозевно и лаяй". Прочитать произведение можно [здесь](https://ilibrary.ru/text/1850/index.html), а английский перевод — [здесь](https://archive.org/details/journeyfromstpet0000radi). Похожая формулировка употреблена на предыдующей странице: "Россия-матерь огромна, игрива и лает, будто волчица во мгле".  В главе 4, Илья описывает родину так: "Распрекрасно снаружи — родина. text: Dancing. This word is crucial to Sokolov's art. Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the  dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek "χορεία" and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools*, is dedicated to Vita Pliaskina, which refers to Sydenham's chorea (also known as "St. Vitus's dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wTCnbga3sqg).  Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

text: The name Emeli'an (Emil) is derived from the Latin name Aemilianus, which means "rival/competitor" or "imitating." In this context, it's a fitting name given the relationship between Ilya and his brother, as well as the fluid nature of the divisions between characters' identities. Aemilianus was also briefly Roman emperor in 253. Ostanin notes that Emel'yan was also the name of Pugachyov, a Cossack ataman who led a popular insurrection during the reign of Catherine the Great (52). text: A town located on the Volga in the Yaroslavl oblast. It is famous for the assassination of Ivan the Terrible's son, Dmitry (here recalled also through the grandson's name), who was sent to Uglich in 1584 after his father died. The 10-year-old boy was found dead on May 15, 1591, his throat cut in the palace courtyard. Although suspicion fell on the tsar's chief advisor, Boris Godunov, official investigators concluded that Dmitry's death was an accident. The story is mentioned also in Pushkin's play "Boris Godunov" (1831).

text: The name Emeli'an (Emil) is derived from the Latin name Aemilianus, which means "rival/competitor" or "imitating." In this context, it's a fitting name given the relationship between Ilya and his brother, as well as the fluid nature of the divisions between characters' identities. Aemilianus was also briefly Roman emperor in 253. Ostanin notes that Emel'yan was also the name of Pugachyov, a Cossack ataman who led a popular insurrection during the reign of Catherine the Great (52). His figure turned literary thanks to Pushkin and his historical novel *The Captain's Daughter* (1836).
ru_trans: Имя Емельян (Эмиль) образовано от латинского имени Aemilianus (Эмилиан), что означает "соперник" или "подражатель". Эмилиан также недолго был римским императором в 253 году. Останин замечает, что Емельяном также звали казацкого атамана, предводителя крупного восстания во время правления Екатерины Великой (Ostanin 52). text: The highest ranked Christian angel class, the seraphim are best known from the [Book of Isaiah (6:1–8)](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=%D0%98%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B8%D1%8F%206%3A1-8&version=RUSV,NIV): "In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord, high and exalted, seated on a throne; and the train of his robe filled the temple. Above him were seraphim, each with six wings: With two wings they covered their faces, with two they covered their feet, and with two they were flying. And they were calling to one another: 'Holy, holy, holy is the Lord Almighty; the whole earth is full of his glory.'" They are also mentioned in Alexander Pushkin's seminal 1826 poem "The Prophet": "Tormented by a spiritual thirst, / I stumbled through a gloomy waste, / And there a six-winged seraph / Appeared before me at the crossroad." Read the original and this English translation [here](http://max.mmlc.northwestern.edu/mdenner/Demo/texts/prophet.htm). Previously mentioned in chapter 4 (R180/E54).

Вокруг Него стояли Серафимы; у каждого из них по шести крыл: двумя закрывал каждый лице свое, и двумя закрывал ноги свои, и двумя летал. И взывали они друг ко другу и говорили: Свят, Свят, Свят Господь Саваоф! вся земля полна славы Его!". Также упоминаются в судьбоносном стихотворении А. Пушкина 1826 года "Пророк": "Духовной жаждою томим, / В пустыне мрачной я влачился, - / И шестикрылый серафим / На перепутьи мне явился". Прочитать стихотворение в оригинале и английском переводе можно [здесь](http://max.mmlc.northwestern.edu/mdenner/Demo/texts/prophet.htm). Упоминались ранее в главе 4 (R180/E54).
